lexUnit.name: in case.scon
lexUnit.definition: FN: (of an uncertain situation) occurring dependent on (an unlikely or undesirable possibility).

sentence.text: In case you 'd forgetten , this is n't the Middle Ages .
Just in case it 's worth mending .
Just in case you missed it , there 's a few on the walls inside too .
In case you did n't know , it 's National Chip Week .
In case of permanent use , purchasing or leasing ( normally for 24 or 36 months ) is probably the most economic way .
In case it 's escaped you , this is n't London .
In case anyone is wondering , I read this cover to cover on the flight home , when I am a most captive audience for almost any reading material .
In case you have n't noticed , the tune is basically the same as the old one , but considerably jazzed up .
In case of doubt the court has to guess what meaning Parliament would have picked on if it had thought of the point .
In case of doubt , that doubt falls to be resolved in favour of the preservation of life for if the individual is to override the public interest , he must do so in clear terms .
In case of public tender , the invitation must be published in at least two daily newspapers with national circulation .
Do n't forget -- in case of fire , you 'll need to find your keys quickly .
In case you get any ideas buster , that car behind is full of friends of mine . "
In case you 're wondering why that is , I 'm going to tell you !
In case anything went wrong , I was prepared to make a dash for Armstrong .
In case of sudden death , take note of any witnesses and anything which may be needed in a statement for a coroner 's inquest .
` Selections " also offers the option of SelectCare protection , which means that in case of redundancy or sickness the regular monthly repayments will be taken care of .
